definitions: large cylindrical container typically made of wood or metal for storing liquids
metal tube through which a bullet travels when a gun is fired
unit of liquid volume equal to forty-two gallons in petroleum measurement
examples: The wine aged in oak barrels for two years
Workers rolled heavy barrels across the warehouse floor
The rifle barrel needed cleaning after target practice
He stared down the barrel of the loaded pistol
Oil prices rose to ninety dollars per barrel yesterday
The refinery processes thousands of barrels of crude daily

definitions: temporary structure erected to block passage or provide protection from attack
fortified position created hastily using available materials during conflict or protest
examples: Police set up barricades to control the parade crowd
The fallen tree created a natural barricade across the road
Protesters built barricades from overturned cars and debris
The revolutionaries defended their barricades throughout the night

definitions: structure or object that prevents movement or access between areas
circumstance or obstacle that makes progress or communication difficult or impossible
examples: The concrete barrier separated the highway lanes for safety
Security barriers surrounded the government building entrance
Language barriers prevented effective communication between the teams
High costs remain a significant barrier to college education

definitions: neighborhood in a city where Spanish-speaking residents predominantly live
district or quarter in a Spanish-speaking country or community
examples: The barrio celebrated its cultural heritage with an annual festival
She grew up in the barrio of East Los Angeles
The old barrio retained its colonial architecture and charm
Local artists painted murals throughout the barrio streets

definitions: lawyer qualified to argue cases in higher courts particularly in British and Commonwealth legal systems
examples: The barrister presented compelling evidence to the jury
She hired an experienced barrister to handle her appeal
The young barrister wore traditional court dress including wig and gown
Barristers must complete specialized training at the Inns of Court

definitions: small cart with one or two wheels pushed by hand for carrying loads
ancient mound of earth or stones placed over a burial site
male pig that has been castrated before reaching sexual maturity
examples: The gardener pushed a barrow full of compost across the lawn
Street vendors sold fruit from wooden barrows at the market
Archaeologists excavated the Bronze Age barrow on the hillside
The ancient barrow contained pottery and bronze artifacts
The farmer raised barrows for meat production on his farm
Barrows grow faster and produce leaner meat than boars

definitions: person who mixes and serves alcoholic drinks at a bar or tavern
examples: The bartender mixed cocktails with impressive flair and speed
She worked as a bartender while attending college classes
The experienced bartender knew every regular customer's favorite drink
Bartenders often serve as informal therapists to their patrons

definitions: system of exchange where goods or services are directly traded without using money
examples: Ancient civilizations relied on barter before currency was invented
They used a barter system to trade vegetables for eggs
The prisoner camp developed an informal barter economy using cigarettes
Rural communities still practice barter for certain goods and services

definitions: dark fine-grained volcanic rock formed from rapidly cooled lava rich in iron and magnesium
examples: The Hawaiian islands consist primarily of basalt from volcanic eruptions
Ancient builders used basalt blocks for monuments and sculptures
Columnar basalt formations create spectacular natural landmarks like Giant's Causeway
The ocean floor contains vast expanses of basalt rock

definitions: lowest part or foundation that supports something from beneath
military installation serving as headquarters and operational center
fundamental principle or starting point from which something develops
substance that accepts hydrogen ions and has pH greater than seven
number used as foundation in a mathematical counting system
examples: The statue stood on a marble base in the town square
The lamp base needed repair after it cracked
Soldiers returned to base after completing their mission
The air force base housed fighter jets and bombers
Trust forms the base of any healthy relationship
The research provided a base for further scientific study
Sodium hydroxide is a strong base used in soap making
The base neutralized the acid in the chemical reaction
Binary uses base two while decimal uses base ten
Computer scientists work with base sixteen hexadecimal numbers

definitions: team sport played with bat and ball between two teams of nine players on a diamond-shaped field
white leather-covered ball with red stitching used in the sport of baseball
examples: Baseball remains America's traditional pastime despite competition from other sports
The kids played baseball every afternoon at the neighborhood park
The pitcher gripped the baseball carefully before throwing a curveball
The autographed baseball became his most treasured possession

definitions: standard or reference point against which things can be compared or assessed
back boundary line at each end of a tennis or basketball court
examples: Scientists established a baseline for measuring climate change over decades
The study used 2010 data as a baseline for comparison
The tennis player served from behind the baseline with power
She ran to the baseline to retrieve the deep shot

definitions: floor of a building that is partly or entirely below ground level
examples: They converted the basement into a home theater and game room
Water flooded the basement during the heavy rainstorm
The old house had a dark basement full of storage boxes
She heard strange noises coming from the basement at night

definitions: informal party or celebration often involving music and dancing
forceful blow or impact that causes damage or injury
examples: They threw a birthday bash with over hundred guests attending
The company's annual bash featured live music and gourmet food
The car took a bash to the front bumper in the accident
He gave the stuck door a bash with his shoulder

definitions: essential facts or principles that form the foundation of a subject or skill
examples: Students must master the basics before advancing to complex topics
The cooking class covered basics like knife skills and sauce making
He returned to basics after his complicated strategies failed
Understanding the basics of finance helps with personal budgeting

definitions: aromatic herb with green leaves commonly used in Mediterranean and Asian cooking
examples: Fresh basil leaves enhanced the tomato sauce with aromatic flavor
She grew several varieties of basil in her herb garden
Thai basil adds distinctive anise notes to Southeast Asian dishes
The pesto required two cups of fresh basil leaves

definitions: large important church building often with special ceremonial rights granted by the Pope
examples: St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City attracts millions of pilgrims annually
The ancient basilica featured stunning Byzantine mosaics
The basilica's architecture included a long nave and side aisles
Local Catholics attended Sunday mass at the historic basilica

definitions: legendary reptile whose gaze or breath was said to be fatal
tropical American lizard that can run on its hind legs across water
examples: Medieval texts described the basilisk as the king of serpents
The basilisk in the story could kill with a single glance
The green basilisk escaped predators by running across the pond surface
Basilisk lizards are sometimes called Jesus Christ lizards for walking on water

definitions: bowl-shaped container or fixture used for holding water for washing
natural depression in earth's surface often containing water or sediment
entire geographical area drained by a river and its tributaries
examples: She filled the basin with warm water to wash her face
The porcelain basin cracked and needed immediate replacement
The ancient basin once held a prehistoric lake millions of years ago
Rainwater collected in the natural basin between the hills
The Amazon basin covers over seven million square kilometers
Agricultural runoff affected water quality throughout the river basin

definitions: container made of interwoven materials used for carrying or storing items
circular rim with net through which the ball must pass to score in basketball
examples: She carried fresh bread in a wicker basket from the bakery
The Easter basket overflowed with colorful eggs and candy
He shot the ball through the basket for three points
The basket hung ten feet above the gymnasium floor

definitions: team sport where players score by shooting a ball through elevated hoops
inflated orange ball used in the sport of basketball
examples: Basketball gained global popularity through the NBA and Olympics
The high school basketball team practiced every afternoon
He dribbled the basketball down court with impressive skill
The leather basketball needed more air before the game

definitions: art or craft of making baskets and other objects by weaving flexible materials
examples: Native American basketry represents centuries of cultural tradition and skill
She learned basketry techniques using willow and reed materials
The museum displayed intricate basketry from various indigenous cultures
Traditional basketry methods pass from generation to generation

definitions: musician who plays the bass guitar or double bass in a band or orchestra
examples: The jazz bassist improvised a complex walking bass line
She worked as a session bassist for various recording artists
The rock band's bassist provided the rhythmic foundation for their songs
The orchestra's principal bassist performed a difficult solo passage

definitions: large double-reed woodwind instrument with a distinctive low pitch played in orchestras and bands
examples: The bassoon provided deep, resonant tones in the symphony's opening
Learning bassoon requires mastering the complex double reed technique
The orchestra's bassoon section played the humorous grandfather theme
She rented a bassoon from the music store for band class

definitions: North American linden tree with soft pale wood used for carving and furniture making
examples: Basswood grows rapidly in moist forest soils throughout the region
The carpenter selected basswood for its easy carving properties
Native Americans used basswood bark to make rope and baskets
The basswood tree attracted bees with its fragrant summer flowers

definitions: archaic or offensive term for a child born to unmarried parents
informal term for an unpleasant or despicable person
something that is irregular, inferior, or of dubious origin
examples: Historical novels often featured bastards struggling for inheritance rights
The king's bastard son could not legally claim the throne
That bastard cheated me out of my fair share
Don't be such a bastard to your coworkers
The manuscript was written in bastard Latin mixed with vernacular
They served a bastard version of authentic Italian cuisine

definitions: projecting part of a fortification built at an angle to the line of a wall
institution or person strongly defending particular principles, attitudes, or activities
examples: The castle's bastion provided defenders with a commanding view
Enemy cannons bombarded the fortress bastion throughout the siege
The university remained a bastion of free speech and academic freedom
The newspaper served as a bastion against government corruption

definitions: nocturnal flying mammal with membranous wings and echolocation abilities
wooden or metal club used for hitting the ball in sports like baseball or cricket
turn or opportunity to hit the ball in baseball or cricket
examples: Bats emerged from the cave at dusk to hunt insects
The fruit bat hung upside down from the tree branch
He swung the aluminum bat and hit a home run
The cricket bat was made from willow wood
She was next at bat with bases loaded
Each player gets three turns at bat per game

definitions: quantity of goods or materials produced or processed together at one time
group of records or programs processed as a single unit in computing
examples: The bakery prepared a fresh batch of cookies every morning
The factory produced batches of five hundred units each
The system processed the batch of transactions overnight
She ran a batch script to update all the files

definitions: act of washing the body by immersing in water
large container filled with water for washing the body
therapeutic treatment involving immersion in water or other substances
examples: The baby enjoyed her evening bath before bedtime
A hot bath helped relieve his sore muscles
The Victorian bath stood on decorative claw feet
She filled the bath with warm water and bubbles
The spa offered mineral baths for health and relaxation
Athletes use ice baths to reduce inflammation after training

definitions: public building containing facilities for bathing, swimming, or relaxation
examples: The Japanese bathhouse offered traditional hot spring bathing experiences
Ancient Roman bathhouses served as important social gathering places
The beach bathhouse provided changing rooms and shower facilities
The historic bathhouse has been restored as a community center

definitions: act of washing or immersing the body in water for cleansing
recreational activity of swimming or playing in water
examples: Daily bathing became common practice in the twentieth century
The doctor recommended bathing the wound twice daily
Beach bathing attracted tourists to the coastal resort
Public bathing areas required appropriate swimwear

definitions: room containing a toilet and sink, typically also a bathtub or shower
examples: The master bathroom featured marble countertops and a walk-in shower
She decorated the guest bathroom with coastal themed accessories
The restaurant bathroom needed cleaning after the lunch rush
They renovated the old bathroom with modern fixtures

definitions: large container for water in which a person may bathe, typically a permanent fixture in a bathroom
examples: The antique bathtub had ornate claw feet and brass fixtures
She filled the bathtub with hot water and bath salts
The plumber replaced the old bathtub with a modern jetted model
Children splashed happily in the bathtub during bath time

definitions: technique of decorating fabric using wax and dye, originating from Indonesia
examples: The artisan created intricate batik patterns using traditional methods
Indonesian batik was recognized by UNESCO as cultural heritage
She wore a beautiful batik dress to the cultural festival
The workshop taught batik techniques using wax and indigo dye

definitions: thin stick used by a conductor to direct an orchestra or choir
short rod passed between runners in a relay race
short stick or club carried as a weapon by police officers
examples: The conductor raised his baton to begin the symphony
She waved the baton gracefully to guide the orchestra's tempo
The runner dropped the baton during the relay handoff
Each team member practiced passing the baton smoothly
Police officers carried batons for crowd control situations
The security guard's baton hung from his utility belt

definitions: player whose turn it is to bat in cricket, positioned to hit the ball
examples: The batsman scored a century before being caught out
Australia's opening batsman faced hostile fast bowling
The batsman defended his wicket throughout the difficult session
Each batsman must wear protective gear including pads and helmet

definitions: large military unit typically consisting of three hundred to one thousand soldiers organized into several companies
examples: The battalion advanced across the battlefield at dawn
She commanded an infantry battalion during the peacekeeping mission
The entire battalion participated in the training exercise
Two battalions were deployed to secure the strategic position

definitions: thin strip of wood used for various construction or reinforcement purposes
strips used to secure the edges of a tarpaulin over a ship's hatch
examples: Carpenters nailed battens to the wall before installing siding
The theatrical backdrop hung from wooden battens overhead
Sailors secured the battens before the storm hit
The phrase 'batten down the hatches' comes from nautical practice

definitions: mixture of flour, eggs, and liquid used in cooking and baking
player at bat attempting to hit the ball in baseball
sustained attack or beating causing damage through repeated blows
examples: She whisked the pancake batter until it was smooth
The cake batter filled two round baking pans
The batter stepped up to the plate with confidence
The pitcher struck out three batters in a row
Waves battered the coastal seawall during the hurricane
Years of storms had battered the old lighthouse

definitions: continuous violent attack or beating causing severe damage or injury
examples: The castle walls withstood the battering from enemy catapults
The ship took a severe battering in the storm
Years of battering had weakened the structural supports
The coastline showed signs of constant battering by waves

definitions: device that stores electrical energy for portable power supply
unlawful physical attack or beating of another person
military unit of artillery guns or missile launchers
set of similar items or devices used together
examples: The car battery died and needed immediate replacement
She charged her phone battery before the long trip
He was arrested and charged with battery after the fight
The victim pressed battery charges against her attacker
The artillery battery fired shells at enemy positions
A battery of anti-aircraft guns defended the airfield
The patient underwent a battery of medical tests
The job applicant faced a battery of interview questions

definitions: action or skill of hitting the ball in baseball or cricket
sheets of cotton or synthetic material used as padding in quilts
examples: His batting average improved dramatically this season
The team practiced batting against different pitching styles
She layered batting between the quilt top and backing
The craft store sold batting in various thicknesses

definitions: violent combat between opposing military forces in warfare
sustained effort to overcome a difficult situation or achieve something
examples: The battle lasted three days with heavy casualties on both sides
Historians study the battle tactics used at Waterloo
She fought a long battle against cancer with courage
The company faces an uphill battle to regain market share

definitions: area where a battle is fought between opposing military forces
examples: The battlefield stretched across several miles of open terrain
Archaeologists discovered artifacts on the ancient battlefield
Veterans returned to visit the battlefield fifty years later
The battlefield has been preserved as a national monument

definitions: foremost line where opposing armies engage in active combat
examples: Supplies were urgently needed at the battlefront
Reporters risked their lives covering stories from the battlefront
Fresh troops reinforced the weakening battlefront at dawn
Communications from the battlefront arrived hours late

definitions: place where a battle is fought or where conflict and competition occur
examples: The valley became a battleground between rival armies
Civil War battlegrounds attract thousands of tourists annually
The state emerged as a key political battleground
Social media became a battleground for competing ideologies

definitions: person who struggles persistently and courageously against difficulties
examples: She was a real battler who never gave up despite setbacks
The team's battlers fought hard until the final whistle
Cancer battlers shared their stories at the support group
He admired battlers who overcame poverty through hard work

definitions: large heavily armored warship with powerful guns used in naval warfare
strategy board game where players try to sink opponent's fleet
examples: The battleship's sixteen-inch guns could strike targets twenty miles away
World War Two marked the end of the battleship era
The children played battleship on rainy afternoons
She sank his battleship with a lucky guess

definitions: sedimentary rock that is the primary ore from which aluminum is extracted
examples: Australia leads the world in bauxite mining and production
The refinery processes bauxite into alumina before aluminum extraction
Bauxite deposits formed over millions of years in tropical climates
The red color of bauxite comes from iron oxide content
